data.text: As a Woman: Bicycle Touring and Wild-Camping Alone
Any women do this alone? How’s it been?

I’ve done it alone in China, which is super safe. I’m starting another bike trip tomorrow, Tenerife, also pretty damn safe. There are definitely places I would not go biking alone. And in all others, general solo travelers advice: don’t flaunt expensive stuff, travel during daytime hours, always have a charged phone and a power bank (and preferably a local SIM card). How has it been? Amazing! Traveling alone gives you a lot of freedom and also helps you meet new people.
data.author: Kay Anky JS

data.text: did you wild-camp in China?
data.author: Giulia Juhé

data.text: nope, not legal! I adjusted my itinerary to the availability of hotels 🙂 that’s why I had some 40km days. (I traveled around Qinghai lake - not many people, villages, or accommodation options there)
data.author: Kay Anky JS

data.text: Hi Anky ! Is it allowed to wild-camp in Tenerife ? Wish you the best on your bike trip there !
data.author: Sammy Ver

data.text: hi, I don’t really know, as I will be staying in hostels - I’m traveling super light and my trip isn’t exclusively on a bike 🙂 Thank you!

data.text: cycled for 3 months in the south of China and a month in north-west, where it's prohibited. Camped wild most of the time.
data.author: Ewa Świderska

data.text: Dangerous for guys too.. carry a electic shocker and bear spray. Good stick, knife. Plan your trip ... travel light . Disappear camp when no ones looking. Day time . If unlucky and just unlucky never know but its usually at night. Trust your gut . I met small little australian guy biking . One might he was scared gang of guys near by but nothing happened ... camping in nz ... electricity or pepper spray detours anything even if shocking your self . Lol.

data.text: , as u know, EVERYTHING is illegal in China, except shopping !

data.author: Rohan D'angelo

data.text: during my cycling trips I found plenty of land (vineyards, /non/agricultural fields, forests and just tucked away green spaces in between towns. I followed the Eurovelo on the Mediterranean and the Atlantic coasts as well as Canal du Midi. I was surprised by how much relative wilderness there was between the islands of civilization. And the French are happy to let you camp on their land and offer showers and meals and wonderful hospitality.

data.text: I've seen plenty of lone female cyclists. And they all look fine to me.
data.author: Neil Hornby

data.text: A bicyclist was just hit by a truck the other day and he was at a bike crossing. We have lived all over the US and find drivers to be rude and careless. I was almost hit even though I had the right of way, was wearing a bright red jacket, and had my hand up for him to stop. As far as violence goes I don't feel safe here as a woman and men are victims too. We have race problems, class problems, and we are a rape culture. In some cities there are robberies in broad daylight and smash and grab is becoming so common that people are not leaving anything in their cars. You would make an easy target not knowing the street culture.
data.author: Ceecee Gowin

data.text: where are you from? I am from California, but would like to bike the eurovelos…
data.author: Alison Smith Loeprich

data.text: I biked by myself in Europe. When I ran into problems I asked the locals for help and received quick helpful answers. When I asked other Americans they acted as if they had no time to answer my questions. It might be my impression but Europeans were far more helpful and had far far better manners. I don't blame them for thinking Americans are snobs. Their kids are better behaved too unfortunately. It might be why they have less crime. Go for it!
data.author: Ceecee Gowin

data.text: You are in less danger on the open road than in a town or city,use your wits and trust your senses. You'll be fine.

data.author: Alison Smith Loeprich

data.text: I follow quite a few of them in social media and YouTube, but I don't know if they are members of this group as many are non-English speaking. From a "courage" to do it point of view I think there is little gender difference these days, but the stats I collect on my own and see from other sources all indicate that cycling is still a male dominant sport. Some 6-7 years ago my own stats were indicating about 19% of all cyclist were female. These days the number is more around 25%. So, while it is very likely most people touring solo are still male, the number of female solo tourers has likely increased over the years also. There is a growing number of couples touring together as well. Keep in mind all of this, regardless of male or female has been hugely affected by the pandemic.
data.author: Paulo Seth

data.author: Lucy Sturgess

data.text:
Of course. Why women wouldn't? But of course it's different than being a man. I've been living on a bike for more than 8 years, know solo cycling ladies that have been doing it for longer and lots of doing shorter trips. Europe, especially the western one like France or Italy, no issues usually. Solo cycling woman attracts more attention once you go east. I've cycled most of Asia, Europe and some Middle East (came back solo from Asia to Europe on a bicycle) and yes, especially in the last one you've got to be careful even not to smile to much to strangers. Proposals for sex happen yes, keep your distance and be firm. I wrote about it a long time ago, new experience since then https://www.ewcyna.com/en/this-is-a-mens-world-czy-kobieta-podrozujaca-solo-ma-sie-czego-bac/
This is a men’s world.. czy kobieta w samotnej podróży musi się bać?
ewcyna.com

Never experienced any more issues than we women (or cyclists in general) face while doing anything else. If traveling on a rail-trail or in the woods or countryside there’s actually significantly less chance of danger.
data.author: Hunter Blackthorne

data.text: I always travel solo, even when hitchhiking or using local and regional buses. So far I have been in NZ, AU, CA (6 month - hade an old and rusty dodge van and did a lot of wild camping), US, MEX (10+ months) and Belize plus traveling in Europe. Last year I was going by bike - also solo, of course. I plan now for a cycle trip from Sweden (my home country) to Egypt and back. I try to see as many countries as possible during that trip. I am biking for future! Btw made it to other continents since I retired in 2015 (65 y-o, no early retirement).

data.text: Yes, currently cycling Cairo to Capetown on my own. I’m in Malawi
data.author: Eilidh Ogden

data.text: wow! Where do you sleep? What kind of roads do you pick? How’s the weather?
data.author: Giulia Juhé

data.text:
currently sleeping mainly in guesthouses as they’re about $5. I plan to do more wild camping (did more in Sudan) but I’m often tired and don’t have the energy to negotiate a spot and interact with people(I believe everyone or no one should know you’re there and it’s too populated for stealth here). Mainly bigger roads that vary a lot in quality although today was lots of unsurfaced road. I’m skirting the rainy season- today was hot and sunny, the rains have usually been short and easy to avoid except last week where it was so flooded my brakes stopped working. I wrote a blog about it… https://eilidhonabike.wordpress.com/2022/04/15/day-87-goodbye-again-tanzania/
Day 87: goodbye again Tanzania!
eilidhonabike.wordpress.com
data.author: Eilidh Ogden

data.text: is the traffic heavy on the roads? I’ll read the blog today, thanks!
data.author: Giulia Juhé

data.text: depends on the road. For most of Tanzania l was cycling along a small hard shoulder lane. Cairo and Khartoum were bad. Road out of Nairobi was miserable
data.author: Eilidh Ogden

data.text: does that mean that there are no other options or that you chose those for logistics? Devouring your blog now. Awesome adventure. Thank you for sharing it!
data.author: Giulia Juhé

data.text: both. As I’m limited for time and prefer surfaced roads I often do direct. Sometimes routes are unavoidable. With more time and planning it can definitely be minimised. Or you can cheat with a tuk tuk if it’s too painful Glad you like the blog 🙂
data.author: Eilidh Ogden

data.text: what do you do about malaria and tsetse?
data.author: Giulia Juhé

data.text: I am a cautious person and have a lot of expensive off brand malarone filling up my bag. Doxycycline is way cheaper but is anti biotic so I didn’t want to take it long term. Many do without or take enough malarone for treatment only. Luckily not encountered many tsetse flies. Bug spray seemed to work

data.text: I have a family of six!!! None of them have any adventure in them! I’ll go by myself!
data.author: Alison Smith Loeprich

data.text: my people are busy in life and my direct family would block me ... by myself or die at home... a lot of fear comes from living around the wrong people and place . Bad experience ties you to bad people vs traveling into safer better life... I'd walk now or sail even though water ant my thing . Lol. Time machine I'd quit school and learn languages abroad and working holidays... take my chances vs dead end location. Lol.. ride or die . Ended up on life trap side . Focus on enjoy life , make money and travel ... being thankful for being a live I guess... people got you fearing other people you should fear them . Lol.
data.author: Mosha Monero

data.text: I started a 6 month tour 2 weeks ago (4th tour I've done but this will be the longest). Currently in NE UK. I've been met with kindness and generosity. Prior to leaving I dealt with alot of questions from family/friends on safety etc. It can impact your confidence to get going. I've taken the approach to not set strict goals or measure every metric. No pressure means you can relax. I've tried to keep smiling (no more shouting at crazy drivers 😁). Made a point of saying hello to everyone and when appropriate stopping to chat to people. It's the best mood and confidence booster! In general I am removing worry by being organised and carrying spare kit and food. It may add weight but its worth it to me. I'm loving touring and couldn't recommend this form of travel more! You discover so many places conventional travel would miss. Plus I've seen an incredible amount of wildlife as I've quitely cycled along. Best of luck on your travels.
data.author: Amy Howard

data.text: Traveled Tassie and much of Qld and a few trails in Melbourne. LOVE IT
data.author: Arabella Watson

data.text: I’m kind of afraid to wild camp where I actually live. Mountain lions and grizzly bears…. I live my little tin can camper, I feel safe. But I can’t pull that with a bike!
data.author: Alison Smith Loeprich

data.text: be okay most likely ... dont watch 411 missing shows. People disappear all time in national parks or areas . Lol. Can even be with a group or group disappears too. Coyotes or coywolve, wolves make you nervous... They shouldn't bother you. Be rare . Lol. Pick your adventure ... New Zealand is safe except roads narrow. Some places you cant ride its death trap ... lol. But no dangerous animals... panicking kills and unlucky timing but it usually works out ... lol. Lots haunted places . Then dont camp In a bull's pasture so forth. Probably meet people on the journey in many cases. Travel buddies. Couch surfing page look up bicycle touring . Sure lots groups and routes to start safely on . Place here so haunted people never go back. A water fall in the woods. Hear people screaming and kids . Even touching you ... people have left in the dark. Got in they vehicles and alternators dead... the fear is real ... lol. I feel your pain ... I watched to many mr. Ballens and who knows what's on woods to portal's to things going back and forth... always good to have a friend you trust... you have a fear for a reason... do it when you feel good about it . Lol.
data.author: Mosha Monero

data.text: I have done some solo travel and I enjoyed it immensely!

data.text: Yes, it's no problem doing it alone. Been cycling along the British west and North Coast, three times, along the North and West coast of Norway twice, also in Europe, North East USA (not quite that great, some people are a bit unruly, but usually ok), Zambia (very good, friendly, open people, good roads, I wouldn't camp as there really aren't many good places to do so and too many mosquitoes and have seen quite a few snakes in the morning run over by cars).

data.author: Alison Smith Loeprich

data.text: reading the comments on this thread it seems there's nothing to be envious about but I can understand why you could feel like that, good to see that change slowly happening, still a long way to go
data.author: Eric Wilcock

data.text: as a woman (50 years now) we are sometimes taught we are carrying around this… this thing of value….that you can’t just leave at home if you want to. And that the world is half full of people who are stronger than you and can take it if they wanted to. And of those people, a smaller percentage would indeed just take it if given the opportunity, and are very hostile to the idea we should get to decide what to do with this thing …we can’t even leave at home. But you can’t tell by looking which ones they are by looking . And so our mothers and grandmothers told us… just stay in at night, never go anywhere alone, until you think the chances of bad things happening are a certainty, and more than that, YOUR OWN FAULT. But the glory of being 50 is getting to unpack and evaluate that for yourself. I am just in awe of the women here who either were never fed this, or were able to shed it earlier than I was.. am…
data.author: Alison Smith Loeprich
